times~.c

00001 // times~.c - the *~ signal operator
00002 // SDK example to illustrate platform-safe Altivec optimization
00003 
00004 #include "ext.h"
00005 #include "z_dsp.h"
00006 
00007 /*
00008 
00009 The idea here is that we can create source code that works on multiple
00010 platforms at compile time, and works on both Altivec- and non-Altivec
00011 PowerPC machines at runtime. We do this by isolating Altivec-specific
00012 code inside #ifdefs and using the routines sys_optimize and sys_altivec
00013 that return whether the user can and wants to optimize
00014 to protect non-Altivec machines from crashing.
00015 
00016 The conditions for sys_optimize() to return true:
00017 
00018 1. Altivec-capable machine
00019 2. User has checked Optimize in the DSP Status window
00020 3. Signal Vector size is a multiple of 4
00021 
00022 Another thing is that assuming you are going to want to decide whether to
00023 use optimized code or not, you should only call sys_optimize() in your DSP
00024 method. Then you can assume that the value will not change until your DSP
00025 method is called again. In other words, the change of the user optimization
00026 state is a "triggering event" for a DSP chain recompilation. sys_optimize()
00027 CANNOT be called in your perform routine because it may allocate memory,
00028 and in any case it is SLOW, much slower than storing its current value
00029 in your object or, as is done in the example below, simply putting different
00030 functions (optimized vs. non-optimized) on the DSP call chain depending
00031 on what its value is in your DSP method.
00032 
00033 When you want to use something that is specific to the Altivec compiler,
00034 you need to put it within two things:
00035 
00036 #ifdef __ALTIVEC__
00037 
00038 and
00039 
00040 #pragma altivec_model on
00041 
00042 The first one is true is the compiler is capable of generating altivec
00043 code. This could be true WHETHER OR NOT the actual machine running the
00044 compiler has Altivec instructions! The second tells the compiler to start 
00045 generating these instructions (and therefore, understanding the use of
00046 the word vector etc.). By leaving the
00047 altivec code generation OFF by default in the project settings, we eliminate
00048 the risk that in the future, Altivec optimization might be automatically
00049 performed by the compiler that would crash non-Altivec machines.
00050 
00051 ALSO note that the only include file you need to write altivec code etc. is
00052 z_dsp.h, which includes z_altivec.h. See z_altivec.h for more obscurity...
00053 
00054 */
00055 
00056 void *times_class;
00057 
00058 
00059 typedef struct _times
00060 {
00061     t_pxobject x_obj;
00062     t_float x_val;
00063 #ifdef __ALTIVEC__
00064 #pragma altivec_model on
00065     vector float x_vecVal;
00066 #pragma altivec_model off
00067 #endif // __ALTIVEC__
00068 } t_times;
00069 
00070 t_int *times_perform(t_int *w);
00071 t_int *scale_perform(t_int *w);
00072 void times_float(t_times *x, double f);
00073 void times_int(t_times *x, long n);
00074 #ifdef __ALTIVEC__          // these are our altivec-specific routines
00075 void times_floatAV(t_times *x, double f);
00076 t_int *times_performAV(t_int *w);
00077 t_int *scale_performAV(t_int *w);
00078 #endif 
00079 void times_dsp(t_times *x, t_signal **sp, short *count);
00080 void times_assist(t_times *x, void *b, long m, long a, char *s);
00081 void *times_new(double val);
00082 
00083 int main(void)
00084 {
00085     setup((t_messlist **)&times_class, (method)times_new, (method)dsp_free, (short)sizeof(t_times), 0L, A_DEFFLOAT, 0);
00086     dsp_initclass();
00087     addmess((method)times_dsp, "dsp", A_CANT, 0);
00088     addfloat((method)times_float);
00089     addint((method)times_int);
00090     addmess((method)times_assist, "assist", A_CANT, 0);
00091     class_setname("*~","times~"); // because the filename on disk is different from the object name in Max
00092 
00093     return 0;
00094 }
00095 
00096 // this routine covers both inlets. It doesn't matter which one is involved
00097 void times_float(t_times *x, double f)
00098 {
00099     x->x_val = f;
00100     if (DSP_SIMPLE_OPTIMIZE_TEST_PARAM) 
00101 #ifdef __ALTIVEC__
00102         times_floatAV(x,f);
00103 #else
00104         ;
00105 #endif
00106 }
00107 
00108 void times_int(t_times *x, long n)
00109 {
00110     times_float(x,(double)n);
00111 }
00112 
00113 // here are the two non-vector-optimized perform routines
00114 
00115 t_int *times_perform(t_int *w)
00116 {
00117     t_float *in1,*in2,*out;
00118     int n;
00119 #ifdef DENORM_WANT_FIX              // if we want to fix denormalized floating-point numbers (Windows XP)
00120     float ftmp;
00121 #endif
00122 
00123     if (*(long *)(w[1]))
00124         goto out;
00125     in1 = (t_float *)(w[2]);
00126     in2 = (t_float *)(w[3]);
00127     out = (t_float *)(w[4]);
00128     n = (int)(w[5]);
00129 
00130 #ifdef DENORM_WANT_FIX              // if we want to fix denormalized floating-point numbers (Windows XP)
00131     while (n--) {
00132         ftmp = *in1++ * *in2++;
00133         FIX_DENORM_NAN_FLOAT(ftmp);
00134         *out++ = ftmp;
00135     }
00136 #else
00137     while (n--) *out++ = *in1++ * *in2++; 
00138 #endif
00139 
00140 out:
00141     return (w + 6);
00142 }
00143 
00144 t_int *scale_perform(t_int *w)
00145 {
00146     t_float *in, *out;
00147     float val;
00148     int n;
00149 #ifdef DENORM_WANT_FIX              // if we want to fix denormalized floating-point numbers (Windows XP)
00150     float ftmp;
00151 #endif
00152     
00153     t_times *x = (t_times *)(w[3]);
00154     if (x->x_obj.z_disabled)
00155         goto out;
00156     in = (t_float *)(w[1]);
00157     out = (t_float *)(w[2]);
00158     val = x->x_val;
00159     n = (int)(w[4]);
00160 
00161 #ifdef DENORM_WANT_FIX              // if we want to fix denormalized floating-point numbers (Windows XP)
00162     while (n--) {
00163         ftmp = val * *in++;
00164         FIX_DENORM_NAN_FLOAT(ftmp);
00165         *out++ = ftmp;
00166     }
00167 #else   
00168     while (n--) *out++ = val * *in++; 
00169 #endif
00170 out:
00171     return (w + 5);
00172 }       
00173 
00174 #ifdef __ALTIVEC__
00175 #pragma altivec_model on  // turn AltiVec code generation on                                                
00176 
00177 void times_floatAV(t_times *x, double f)
00178 {
00179     vec_splat_float(x->x_vecVal, f); // copy the new scalar to the vector
00180 }
00181 
00182 // here is an Altivec-optimized routine that multiples two signals together, producing a third signal
00183 // vec_madd(a,b,c) does result = a * (b + c), so we need a zero vector that we initialize locally
00184 
00185 t_int *times_performAV(t_int *w)
00186 {
00187     vector float *v_in1, *v_in2, *v_out, zero;
00188     unsigned int n = (int)(w[5]);           
00189     
00190     if (*(long *)(w[1]))
00191         goto out;
00192     zero = (vector float) (0, 0, 0, 0);
00193     v_in1 = (vector float *)(w[2]);
00194     v_in2 = (vector float *)(w[3]);
00195     v_out = (vector float *)(w[4]);
00196     while (n--) {
00197         *v_out++ = vec_madd(*v_in1++, *v_in2++, zero);
00198     }
00199 out:
00200     return (w + 6);
00201 }
00202 
00203 // here is an Altivec-optimized routine that multiples a signal by a scalar
00204 // vec_madd is used as above, but the val argument refers to the vector
00205 // we stored in our object
00206 
00207 t_int *scale_performAV(t_int *w)
00208 {   
00209     t_times *x = (t_times *)(w[3]);
00210     int n = (int)(w[4]);    
00211     vector float *v_in, *v_out, val, zero;      
00212     floatToVector foo;
00213     
00214     if (x->x_obj.z_disabled) 
00215         goto out;
00216         
00217     zero = (vector float) (0, 0, 0, 0);
00218     v_in =  (vector float *)(w[1]);
00219     v_out = (vector float *)(w[2]);
00220     val = x->x_vecVal;
00221     while (n--) {
00222         *v_out++ = vec_madd(*v_in++, val, zero);
00223     }
00224     
00225 out:
00226     return (w + 5);
00227 } 
00228 
00229 #pragma altivec_model off // turn AltiVec code generation off
00230 #endif // __ALTIVEC__
00231 
00232 
00233 void times_dsp(t_times *x, t_signal **sp, short *count)
00234 {
00235     if (DSP_SIMPLE_OPTIMIZE_TEST(sp[0])) {
00236 #ifdef __ALTIVEC__
00237 #pragma altivec_model on
00238             // we need to do this in case the scalar was stored with optimization off
00239             // and we are just now turning optimization on. See I told you using this
00240             // vector stuff was tricky...
00241         times_floatAV(x,x->x_val);  // splat the vector
00242             // if optimization is on, we are going to use one of our two optimized
00243             // perform routines. We pick the proper one based on whether signals
00244             // are connected to both inlets. If they are, we use times_performAV,
00245             // otherwise we will be multiplying by a scalar
00246         if (!count[1]) 
00247             dsp_add(scale_performAV, 4, sp[0]->s_vec, sp[2]->s_vec, x, (sp[0]->s_n / 4));
00248         else if (!count[0]) 
00249             dsp_add(scale_performAV, 4, sp[1]->s_vec, sp[2]->s_vec, x, (sp[0]->s_n / 4));
00250         else {
00251             dsp_add(times_performAV, 5, &x->x_obj.z_disabled, sp[0]->s_vec, sp[1]->s_vec,
00252                 sp[2]->s_vec, (sp[0]->s_n / 4));
00253         }
00254 #pragma altivec_model off
00255 #else
00256             // this error would be generated at runtime if the code were to be compiled on
00257             // a compiler or machine without ALTIVEC and for some reason sys_optimize returned true
00258         object_error((t_object *)x, "no optimizations available"); // in theory this should never happen...
00259 #endif  // __ALTIVEC__
00260     } else {
00261         if (!count[1])
00262             dsp_add(scale_perform, 4, sp[0]->s_vec, sp[2]->s_vec, x, sp[0]->s_n);
00263         else if (!count[0])
00264             dsp_add(scale_perform, 4, sp[1]->s_vec, sp[2]->s_vec, x, sp[0]->s_n);
00265         else
00266             dsp_add(times_perform, 5, &x->x_obj.z_disabled, sp[0]->s_vec, sp[1]->s_vec,
00267                 sp[2]->s_vec, sp[0]->s_n);
00268     }
00269 }
00270 
00271 void times_assist(t_times *x, void *b, long m, long a, char *s)
00272 {
00273     if (m == ASSIST_OUTLET)
00274         sprintf(s,"(Signal) Multiplication Result");
00275     else {
00276         switch (a) {    
00277         case 0:
00278             sprintf(s,"(Signal/Float) This * Right Inlet");
00279             break;
00280         case 1:
00281             sprintf(s,"(Signal/Float) Left Inlet * This");
00282             break;
00283         }
00284     }
00285 }
00286 
00287 void *times_new(double val)
00288 {
00289     t_times *x = (t_times *)newobject(times_class);
00290     dsp_setup((t_pxobject *)x,2);
00291     outlet_new((t_pxobject *)x, "signal");
00292     x->x_val = val; // splatted in _dsp method if optimizations are on
00293     
00294     return (x);
00295 }
